div1.p: Subject. The transmission of copies of official correspondence between this Consulate General and the Liberian Government.
No. 85. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, November 1, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.
Sir: I have the honor to transmit, herewith, copies of official Consulor correspondence between this Consulate General and the Liberian Government.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith Consul General.
No. 41/1901. Miscellaneous. Legation of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, Oct. 11, 1901.
Hon. W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State, Monrovia.

Sir: By direction of the Secretary of State Washington, I have the honor to hand you herewith, copies of the regulations, also the act of COngress of March 3, 1901, providing for; as well as the regulations issued by the Secretary of the Treasury for the admission of exhibits to the "Louisiana Purchase Exposition" free of duty. I am further directed to assure your Excellency that the Government of the united States still further directs me to emphasis the fact that it is the earnest desire thereof, to see your Government suitably represented at said Louisiana Purchase Exposition.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith, Minister Resident.
Copy
Department of State, Monrovia, Oct. 16, 1901.

Sir: I have the honor to be in receipt of your dispatch of the 11th inst. forwarding this Department under seperate covers copies of the regulations also the Acts of Congress of March 3 20, 1901, providing for as well as the regulations issued by the Secretary of the Treasury for the admission of the Exhibits of the "Louisana Purchase Exposition, free of duty, for which please accept the tanks of the Department. You are further pleased to assure me of the earnestness of your Government that this Government be suitably represented at said "Louisiana Purchase Exposition" which no doubt will be the case.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient Servant, W. V. Gibson, Acting Sec of State
Hon. O. L. W. Smith U.S. Minister Resident & Consul Gen'l Monrovia
Copy.
No. 42/1901, Miscellaneous Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, October 17, 1901.
To the Honorable The Special Commissions, Monrovia, Liberia.

Gentlemen: In reply to the printed list of questions a copy of which is herewith attached that you submitted to me, in common with other foreign Consular representatives residing near this Government in July last to answer, touching the very important matter therein contained, I have the honor to advise you that in answering same as I am not empowered to act nor instructed by my Government upon this very important matter, I can only answer your questions as my own observation, experience an opinions in commercial intercourse with other great Nations and

1. Yes. Let vessels be registered under the Liberian Flag by Liberian Consuls abroad under proper restrictions. 2. A feeling of insecurity exists, especially financial responsibility. 3. Have your monetary system in dollars cents_gold standard maintaining between paper dollars and gold dollars. 4. The Free trade conditions are made with the revenue of the country fully protected, the more likelyhood of trade increaseing. 5. Dashes are in the nature of of bribes and should be abolished everywhere. 6. Yes. Would recommend the Metric System. 7. Yes, Tonnage dues should be a maximum amount each fiscal year divided into multiple payments payable on each entry at any

any Liberian Port of entry. Any unmade payment during the fiscal year to lapse. In connection with this question I have to call your attention to the fact that in order to encourage Commerce, the Liberian Government has very thoughtfully and generously relinquished the charges and dues for anchorage, lights and tonnage upon European steam vessels calling at Liberian Ports carrying the Liberian and Foreign mails in lieu of said changes and dues; and in order to encourage American steam and sail vessels calling at Liberian ports, as in the case of the "Yates and Porterfield Trading Company" of New York, carrying on a large Mercantile business in Freetown, Sierra Leone, and the said company having but recently rented business apartments on Water street and river front in Monrovia with a view

view to an early reestablishment of business in this city, I would most respectfully ask, petition, and recommend to your commission that whereas the said "Yates and Porterfield Trading Company" of New York, operates a fleet of several sailing vessels that whenever the first arrival of one of their vessels occur for the fiscal year that that first arrived vessel be requested to pay a full annual tonnage of 50 cents, per ton burden, for the fiscal year, and that the said or subsequent vessels of the said "Yates and Porterfield Trading Company," be allowed to call as frequently as they may see fit and enter as many Liberian ports as they the said company may see fit to dispatch them, without another or further payment of anchorage, light or

or tonnage charge or dues during the same fiscal year except in the case of a subsequent vessel being of a greater tonnage burden than the one paying the Annual charges and dues, in which case the subsequent vessel shall pay any excess of tonnage dues to the Liberian Government. 8. Yes. 9. Yes. Believing foreign concessions to be detrimental to the country. 10. Increase them if possible upon improved modern scientific principles. 11. No. Restricted immigration is the most desirable and profitable to the country. 12. Cable communication would be a benefit also telegraphic and telephonic communication between the capital, the several ports of entry and the more important interior towns and settlements

settlements so that the head of the Government can be communicated with at any time and at the shortest possible moment, would very materially inprove the commercial interest of the country. Again improve the harbor at Monrovia by building a buakirater off Cape Messerado as well as fostering an attempt to establish steam or sail communication between the United States and the Republic of Liberia.
I have the honor to be yours &c. Owen L. W. Smith.
SPECIAL COMMISSIONERS' ROOM.
Sir, I am directed by the Special Commissioners, to submit the following questions for your consideration; and to respectfully reqeust your answer in writing to the same, at an early a date possible.
I am Sir, Yours &c., &c. D. FRANCIS WARE, SECRETARY.
Mr.
QUESTIONS.

1. Do you think the commerce of Liberia would be improved by adopting ay policy other than those already adopted, if so what would you suggest? 2. What is your opinion as to the condition of trade and commerce in Liberia, especially as they effect foreign traders and merchants? 3. What would you recommend as a change of policy and measures for the better protection of capital in the commerce of the country? 4. Do you think there is a sufficient number of "Ports of Entry" on the coast for the betterment of trade and commerce, and would recommend the opening of the entire coast to foreign traders and merchants,--in that case where should the duties be paid? 5. What is your opinion respecting the high dashes paid to chiefs and town people on the coast both by foreign and Liberian merchants and traders in the face of licenses already paid to Government? 6. In your opinion, should there not be a uniform system of weights and measures on the coast, regulated by government as adopted in the regular ports of entry? 7. In your opinion are the charges on transient vessels for light, anchorage and tonnage dues excessive? 8. Do you think a regularly constituted Board of Trade in every county would be advantageous to the trade in general in Liberia, and what would you suggest or recommend? 9. Do you think that by opening the interior to resident foreign traders and merchants in Liberia, it would aid the development of the trade of the country? 10. Have you any suggestions to offer with regard to the agricultural industries of Liberia, with a view to improvement in the cultivation of cocoa, cocoanuts, coffee, rubber, corn, cotton, peas and other products? 11. Is the shipping of Labourers from Liberia to foreign ports beneficial to the commercial and agricultural interests of the country? 12. Give us your opinion on matters pertaining to trade, agriculture, and other matters of general interest?
C. T. O. KING, CHAIRMAN. J. VIEWEG, W. T. HAGAN.
